results.title: At-Risk Population in Houston
results.description:
This app shows evacuation routes and demographic data by census tract for Houston, Texas. The darker blue tracts have a higher percentage of households without a vehicle. This pattern helps answer the question: Where in Houston should we provide evacuation assistance during a hurricane?

Use the Layers and Legend tools to learn more about the data shown in the map. Click individual census tracts to see pop-up information, including the percentage of households without a vehicle.

The map in this app contains a Living Atlas layer of Houston evacuation routes and a layer of Houston demographic data. The demographic layer is styled using an Arcade expression that calculates the percentage of households without a vehicle. This information is also provided in pop-ups.
results.snippet: This web app highlights areas in need of assistance during a hurricane evacuation in Houston, Texas.

results.title: Red Rock Canyon Hiking Map
results.description:
This map shows the boundaries and visitor's center of the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area.

This map is part of the project Hiking Red Rock Canyon on Learn ArcGIS.
results.snippet: This map was created to assist hikers in planning their day at Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area
results.accessInformation: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management

results.title: Crossing Barriers
results.description: The Crossing Barriers story map is part of the emerging Tri-Cities Conservation Initiative which aims to address human development and conservation issues in the Laramie-Fort Collins-Cheyenne area. The project explains the importance of wildlife migration, addresses wildlife-highway conflict on US 287,  and informs the public of effective mitigation strategies.
results.snippet: The road ahead to safer passages on Highway 287
results.licenseInfo: The Crossing Barriers story map is intended to inform the public of wildlife-highway issues along Highway 287. Given the scope of the project, layers in the story map should only be used for general spatial reference and not for transportation planning.

results.title: Shelter Access AnalysisDM
results.description:
Starting map for an analysis of people who live in high risk zones for lava flow on the island of Hawaii. The analysis considers the locations of emergency shelters, how long it takes to drive to a shelter, and where people live on the island.

This web application is part of the project Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii on the Learn ArcGIS website.
tags: Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii
results.snippet: Analysis map of access to emergency shelters.

results.name: Fire_History_2004_2018
results.title: Fire History 2004_2018
results.description: The Geospatial Multi-Agency Coordination Group, or GeoMAC, is an internet-based mapping tool originally designed for fire managers to access online maps of current fire locations and perimeters in the conterminous 48 states and Alaska. Perimeters are submitted to GeoMAC by field offices and then posted to an FTP site for downloading. This file contains all fire perimeters that were submitted to GeoMAC by field offices for the current year. The projection is geographic and the datum is NAD83.
results.snippet: This layer displays wildfire perimeter data as they are submitted by field offices.

results.title: Site 1- Limon — Site 1- Limon
results.description:
Route and directions for Site 1- Limon — Site 1- Limon

Route Details
  • 373.24 minutes
  • 380.03 miles
  • Route start time: 2020-04-16 23:19:36 UTC
Directions
  1. Start at Site 1- Limon
  2. Go southeast on County Road 187
  3. Continue forward on County Road 166
  4. Bear left on County Road 118
  5. Turn right onto the ramp and go on I-70 W
  6. Take the ramp on the right at exit 274 to I-25 toward Ft Collins / Colo Springs
  7. Keep left at the fork onto I-25 S / I-70 W toward Colo Springs / Pecos St
  8. Keep left at the fork onto I-25 S toward Colo Springs
  9. Keep left at the fork onto I-25 S toward Colo Spgs
  10. Bear right onto the ramp at exit 210A to US-40 / US-287 / Colfax Avenue
  11. Turn left on W Colfax Ave (I-70-BL E)
  12. Turn right on N Broadway
  13. Turn left on E 14th Ave
  14. Turn left on N Sherman St, then turn left on N Sherman St
  15. Arrive at 200 E Colfax Ave, Denver, Colorado, 80203, on the right
  16. Depart 200 E Colfax Ave, Denver, Colorado, 80203
  17. Continue northeast on N Sherman St
  18. Turn left to stay on N Sherman St
  19. Turn left on E Colfax Ave (I-70-BL)
  20. Take the ramp on the right to I-25 toward Fort Collins / Colo Spgs
  21. Keep right at the fork onto I-25 N toward Fort Collins
  22. Take the ramp on the right at exit 216 to I-76 toward Grand Junction / Fort Morgan
  23. Keep right at exit 216A onto I-76 E toward Fort Morgan
  24. Take the ramp on the right at exit 125 to US-6 toward Sterling (CO-14) / Holyoke (US-138)
  25. Keep right at the fork
  26. Bear right on US-6
  27. Turn left on County Road 85
  28. Arrive at Site 2- Fleming, on the left
  29. Depart Site 2- Fleming
  30. Go back south on County Road 85
  31. Turn right on US-6
  32. Turn left onto the ramp and go on I-76 W
  33. Take the ramp on the right to US-6 (I-76-BL)
  34. Turn left on US-6 (I-76-BL) toward CO-71 / US-34
  35. Keep right at the fork toward Brush
  36. Bear right on US-34 (I-76-BL)
  37. Turn left on CO-71
  38. Turn left on I-70-BL E (Main St)
  39. Make a sharp left
  40. Take the ramp on the right and go on I-70 W
  41. Take the ramp on the right at exit 354 to 354
  42. Make a sharp right on County Road 118
  43. Bear right on County Road 166
  44. Continue forward on County Road 187
  45. Finish at Site 1- Limon, on the left

results.title: Analysis quick lesson - Ben Nordbrock
results.description:
This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock in order to reduce the spread of the invasive weed.  The Create Buffers, Find Existing Locations, and Summarize Within tools can be used for this analysis.

This map and its accompanying workflow were created for instructional purposes only and should not be used as an authoritative resource.
results.snippet: This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock.
results.licenseInfo:
This map was create for instructional purposes.

Commercial Campgrounds, Roads, and Nasella Tussock Range are provided under Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 New Zealand
Populated Places was released to public domain by Peter Scott.
Regions is based on/includes Statistics New Zealand’s data which are licensed by Statistics New Zealand for re-use under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

results.title: Fires, Waffle Houses, Obesity
results.description: Striking conclusions made as an in depth analysis was performed, viewing the correlative nature of the absence of waffle houses in the state of California, and the overwhelming presence of fires since the year 2000. Moreover, the highlighted counties are those with at least 30% obesity rates (as per the CDC). California has but two counties that are over 30% obese, while the eastern seaboard is littered with them. In fact, both West Virginia and Missouri, every one of their counties clocks in at over 30%. Simultaneously, the east coast has a smattering of Waffle Houses (home of the All Star Special breakfast, the deal of the century). Curious, no? Is it coincidence? Is it conspiracy? Is there any causation between high rates of obesity and the presence of wildfires? Could this be mitigated by implementation of Waffle Houses? I see no reason why the Californian government does not view this as a solution to their increasingly problematic wildfires. Could it be ignorance? Nevertheless, this map aims to raise awareness, in an effort to fight back at the increasing intensity and frequency of devastating California wildfires by overeating (specifically at the Waffle House).
results.snippet: Striking conclusions made as an indepth analysis was performed, viewing the correlative nature of the absence of waffle houses in the state of California, and the overwhelming presence of fires since the year 2000.

results.title: Black-footed Ferret Reintroduction Map: Spatial Analysis Demo
results.description:
Map of data layers for Black footed ferret reintroduction scenario.
Intended for demo purposes only.
Includes:
Prairie dog range maps 
NLCD land cover
Colorado oil and gas wells -
Colorado cities
Eastern CO roads
Areas unsuitable for reintroduction because they are too close to cities or roads
Potential areas suitable for reintroduction that are far enough away from disturbance and within prairie dog habitat

Created by the Geospatial Centroid at CSU for a hands-on workshop. April 13 2017.
results.snippet: Map of data sources for Black footed ferret reintroduction scenario
results.accessInformation:
Various data layers from various sources including:
GAP, FEMA, FracTracker, CDOT, US Census and derived layers created in ArcMap by the owner.
results.licenseInfo: Intended for demo purposes only, as it is a fairly simplified model.

results.title: CRB_Fed_Lands
results.description: The data for the FedLands dataset was primarily compiled from nationalatlas.gov, Map Layers, the U.S. National Park Service and the U.S. Forest Service. Please visit https://www.nationalatlas.gov/maplayers.html for the source data, data disclaimers and metadata if not available in these data layer files. Much of the metadata for the files in the dataset are complete and were imported with the original file. In cases where there are discrepancies, metadata have been added where appropriate.
results.snippet: The Federal Lands dataset was collected as part of the Colorado River Basin Agricultural Water Governance Project through a collaboration between the Environmental Defense Fund and Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.
results.accessInformation: The FedLands dataset was created by Faith Sternlieb, Colorado State University, 20 December 2012.

results.name: Large_Wildfire_Burn_Probability_for_Next_Fire_Season
results.title: Large Wildfire Burn Probability for Next Fire Season
results.description: This layer is based on the Region 3 wildfire risk assessment completed in 2016. Several modifications were made where ecoregional boundaries produced artifacts in burn probability. This dataset was incorporated into the Data Atlas component of the Statewide Natural Resources Assessment for the 2020 New Mexico Forest Action Plan. The Atlas was prepared principally for use in spatial prioritization of resource protection and restoration strategies over 2020 – 2030 by the New Mexico Energy, Minerals and Natural Resources Department (EMNRD) Forestry Division (Forestry Division) and its partners. Within the Assessment framework, the dataset characterizes the Wildfire major threat factor.
results.snippet: Pixel-level predictions of where large fires will burn, modeled using FSIM. Values represent the probability of that pixel burning in the next fire season.
results.accessInformation: This dataset was incorporated intothe Data Atlas by The Nature Conservancy (TNC) on behalf of the Forestry Division. Source Data: USFS R3 Fire Ecology
results.licenseInfo: The New Mexico Energy, Minerals and Natural Resources Department, Forestry Division (Forestry Division) provides this product for informational purposes only. The Forestry Division and its partners make no representations or warranties of any kind with respect to the accuracy or completeness of this dataset and assume no responsibility of suitable use for legal, engineering, or survey purposes, nor for any other particular application or utility. By any user's reliance on, dissemination of, or reference to these data in whole or in part (use), the user has accepted all limitations of the product, including user's acknowledgement that all spatial data products are dynamic and may change without prior notice and any use is subject to that understanding. User acknowledges that neither the Forestry Division nor its partners are liable for any damages incurred as a result of errors in these data, and user acknowledges use at user's own risk and discretion. This dataset may be used in the creation of derived material, but only if (a) user provides due credit to the data's originator and its curation under the New Mexico 2020 Forest Action Plan, and (b) user indicates if changes were made by the user. They may do so in any reasonable manner, but not in any way that suggests the Forestry Division or its partners endorses them or their use.

results.title: Shelter Access Analysis
results.description:
Starting map for an analysis of people who live in high risk zones for lava flow on the island of Hawaii. The analysis considers the locations of emergency shelters, how long it takes to drive to a shelter, and where people live on the island.

This web application is part of the project Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii on the Learn ArcGIS website.
tags: Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii
results.snippet: Analysis map of access to emergency shelters.

results.snippet: Analysis map of access to emergency shelters.

results.title: At-risk population in houston
results.description:
This app shows evacuation routes and demographic data by census tract for Houston, Texas. The darker blue tracts have a higher percentage of households without a vehicle. This pattern helps answer the question: Where in Houston should we provide evacuation assistance during a hurricane?

Use the Layers and Legend tools to learn more about the data shown in the map. Click individual census tracts to see pop-up information, including the percentage of households without a vehicle.

The map in this app contains a Living Atlas layer of Houston evacuation routes and a layer of Houston demographic data. The demographic layer is styled using an Arcade expression that calculates the percentage of households without a vehicle. This information is also provided in pop-ups.
results.snippet: This web app highlights areas in need of assistance during a hurricane evacuation in Houston, Texas.
results.licenseInfo: None. Public domain data.

results.name: COMap_v10_2019
results.title: BT_COMap_v10_2019
results.description: Colorado Ownership, Management and Protection is a comprehensive dataset of land ownership and management. This version contains data from Federal agencies, State agencies, The Nature Conservancy, city and county sources and land trust sources. Data was collected from multiple sources and processed into one complete layer
results.snippet: To provide a rich and complete picture of the land ownership and management patterns in Colorado.
results.accessInformation:
Credits

Theobald D. M., M. Linneal  and S. Linn. 2019. Colorado Ownership, Management, and Protection V10. Clipped to the Big Thompson River watershed by Luke Chamberlain, intern at The Geospatial Centroid, Colorado State University, 2/19/2020

results.name: Colorado_14ers.lpkx
results.title: Colorado 14ers
results.description: Derived from GNIS data; there are 54 "official" 14,000' in Colorado and 4 "unranked" 14,000' peaks.  The 4 unranked 14ers have less than 300' vertical drop from it's parent peak.
results.snippet: 3D map of Colorado 14ers by Elevation and County border

results.title: Analysis quick lesson - Tracey Malter
results.description:
This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock in order to reduce the spread of the invasive weed.  The Create Buffers, Find Existing Locations, and Summarize Within tools can be used for this analysis.

This map and its accompanying workflow were created for instructional purposes only and should not be used as an authoritative resource.
results.snippet: This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock.
results.licenseInfo:
This map was create for instructional purposes.

Commercial Campgrounds, Roads, and Nasella Tussock Range are provided under Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 New Zealand
Populated Places was released to public domain by Peter Scott.
Regions is based on/includes Statistics New Zealand’s data which are licensed by Statistics New Zealand for re-use under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

results.name: RGB_meantemp_1970_2000_Aug
results.title: RGB_meantemp_1970_2000_Aug
results.description:
Mean Temperature of the Rio Grande River watershed from 1970 to 2000, during the month of August


This is WorldClim 2.0 Beta version 1 (June 2016) downloaded from http://worldclim.org

They represent average monthly climate data for 1970-2000.

Data have been clipped to the Rio Grande Hydrologic Unit
results.snippet: Mean Temperature of the Rio Grande River watershed from 1970 to 2000, during the month of August
results.accessInformation: The data were created by Steve Fick and Robert Hijmans

results.title: Road Trip Home
results.description:
Route and directions for Road Trip Home

Route Details
  • 1,161.99 minutes
  • 1,277.10 miles
Navigator Stop List

Directions
  1. Start at Mountain View, CA, USA
  2. Go southwest on Castro St
  3. Turn left on W El Camino Real (CA-82 S)
  4. Turn left on CA-237 E (Mountain View Alviso Rd)
  5. Take ramp on the left to I-880 N (Nimitz Fwy)
  6. At fork keep left on I-880 N toward Oakland
  7. At exit 12A bear right onto ramp to Mission Blvd toward Sacramento (I-680)
  8. Continue on Mission Blvd (CA-262 E)
  9. Take ramp on the right to I-680 N toward Sacramento
  10. At fork keep left on I-680 N toward Sacramento
  11. Take ramp on the right and go on I-80 E toward Sacramento
  12. Take ramp on the right and go on I-80 E toward Reno
  13. Take ramp to I-15 S (I-80 E)
  14. At fork keep left on I-80 E / I-15 S toward Cheyenne / Las Vegas
  15. At exit 304 keep right on I-80 E toward Cheyenne
  16. Go on I-80 E
  17. At exit 359A take ramp on the right and go on I-25 S toward Denver / US-80 S
  18. At exit 240 take ramp on the right toward CO-119 W / Firestone Blvd
  19. Turn left on CO-119 E
  20. Continue on County Road 24 (Firestone Blvd)
  21. Turn right on Colorado Blvd (County Road 13)
  22. Turn left on W Grant Ave (County Road 18)
  23. Finish at Firestone, CO, USA, on the right
results.snippet: Route and directions for Road Trip Home
results.licenseInfo: Use subject to Esri Terms of Use

This map and its accompanying workflow were created for instructional purposes only and should not be used as an authoritative resource.

results.title: CRB_California
results.description: The data for the California dataset was primarily compiled from CalAtlas Geospatial Clearinghouse (https://www.dot.ca.gov/hq/tsip/gis/datalibrary/gisdatalibrary.html) and the Redlands Institute. Please visit their websites and for the source data, data disclaimers and metadata if not available in these data layer files. Much of the metadata for the files in the dataset are complete and were imported with the original file. In cases where there are discrepancies, metadata have been added where appropriate.
results.snippet: The California dataset was collected as part of the Colorado River Basin Agricultural Water Governance Project through a collaboration between the Environmental Defense Fund and Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.
results.accessInformation: The California dataset was created by Faith Sternlieb, Colorado State University, 20 December 2012.

results.name: CLP_HUC10
results.title: CLP_HUC10
results.description: Hydrologic Unit delineation are closed polygons that encompass all area draining toward the lowest point (called outlet or pour point) in the polygon. Because of varying sizes for the different hydrologic unit levels: some polygons do not include all areas up to the drainage divide, but all areas are included up to one or more other upstream hydrologic units. A unique hydrologic unit code is used to identify each hydrologic unit. The hydrologic unit codes start with the 2-digit Region number that contains the 4-, 6-, and 8-digit hydrologic units. Each hydrologic unit has a unique hydrologic code.
results.snippet: This dataset is intended to be used as a tool for water-resource management and planning activities, particularly for site-specific and localized studies...
results.accessInformation: USDA/NRCS - National Geospatial Center of Excellence, 02/20/2014. Downloaded by Nick Vogel, intern at The Geospatial Centroid, Colorado State University, 05/13/20

results.title: majorcities-MaryamExersise2-
results.description:
This map was created for mapping and visualizing data about volcanoes in the Cascades Range.

The map contains the following layers:
  • Selected volcanoes of the Cascades Range
  • Earthquakes 2012-2014 (3 years), magnitude 5.7 and greater
  • Tectonic plate boundaries
  • Major cities of the world
The data and related materials are made available through Esri (http://www.esri.com) and are intended for educational purposes only (see Access and Use Constraints section).
results.snippet: Map for examining volcanoes in the Cascades Range of the U.S. Pacific Northwest.
results.accessInformation: USGS, Esri Training Services - for educational purposes only
results.licenseInfo:

results.name: BT_NED_Aspect
results.title: BT_NED_Aspect
results.description:
This tile layer is derived from NED to the Big Thompson watershed 
boundary. The National Elevation Dataset (NED) is a seamless raster 
product 
primarily derived from USGS 10- and 30-meter Digital Elevation Models 
(DEMs). NED data are available from The National Map Viewer as 1 
arc-second (approximately 30 meters) for the CONUS, and at 1/3 and 1/9 
arc-seconds (approximately 10 and 3 meters, respectively) for parts of 
the United States. - from the USGS National Map web site
   Constraints:
   Not to be used for navigation, for informational purposes only. See 
full disclaimer for more information
results.snippet: Aspect raster dataset of the Big Thompson watershed derived from national elevation dataset. Clipped to watershed boundary by CSU Geospatial Centroid intern Luke Chamberlain. April, 2020.

results.title: Fort Collins Public Engagement Opportunities of Populations Less Than 30 Years Old
results.description: This map was created by CSU student Hanna Johnson for her senior political science capstone project. The layer that displays high concentrations of populations under 30 years old was derived from 2010 Census data acquired from the State of Colorado Demographic website. The resulting layer highlights high percentages of populations ages 0-30. These areas seem to be centered around Colorado State University especially near the West Elizabeth corridor. Other layers highlight possible public engagement opportunities in areas with high concentrations of young populations. This includes restaurants, bars, and apartment complexes.
results.snippet: Based on 2010 Census Data by Tract, this map aims to target engagement opportunities with populations less than 30 years old in Fort Collins, CO.
results.licenseInfo: This is a not a professional analysis, and I am not liable for outside use of these layers.

results.title: Pacific Northwest Volcanoes-Copy Maryam Exercise2
results.description:
This map was created for mapping and visualizing data about volcanoes in the Cascades Range.

The map contains the following layers:
  • Selected volcanoes of the Cascades Range
  • Earthquakes 2012-2014 (3 years), magnitude 5.7 and greater
  • Tectonic plate boundaries
  • Major cities of the world
The data and related materials are made available through Esri (http://www.esri.com) and are intended for educational purposes only (see Access and Use Constraints section).
results.snippet: Map for examining volcanoes in the Cascades Range of the U.S. Pacific Northwest.
results.accessInformation: USGS, Esri Training Services - for educational purposes only

results.title: Shelter Access Analysis
results.description:
Starting map for an analysis of people who live in high risk zones for lava flow on the island of Hawaii. The analysis considers the locations of emergency shelters, how long it takes to drive to a shelter, and where people live on the island.

This web application is part of the project Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii on the Learn ArcGIS website.
tags: Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii
results.snippet: Analysis map of access to emergency shelters.

results.title: Analysis quick lesson - Christina
results.description:
This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock in order to reduce the spread of the invasive weed.  The Create Buffers, Find Existing Locations, and Summarize Within tools can be used for this analysis.

This map and its accompanying workflow were created for instructional purposes only and should not be used as an authoritative resource.
results.snippet: This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock.
results.licenseInfo:
This map was create for instructional purposes.

Commercial Campgrounds, Roads, and Nasella Tussock Range are provided under Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 New Zealand
Populated Places was released to public domain by Peter Scott.
Regions is based on/includes Statistics New Zealand’s data which are licensed by Statistics New Zealand for re-use under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

results.name: Water_Planning_Areas_RG
results.title: Water_Planning_Areas_RG
results.description:
Water planning areas in Colorado, New Mexico and Texas.


This file is a combination of the the Texas water planning areas (http://www.twdb.texas.gov/waterplanning/rwp/index.asp) and the water districts of Colorado and New Mexico.
results.snippet: Water planning areas in Colorado, New Mexico and Texas.
results.accessInformation: Created by the Solis group from UC-Davis as a part of their geodatabase for the Rio Grande Basin. Metadata created by Kristin Davis (Geospatial Centroid intern) following email conversations with Jose Pablo Ortiz Partida (goes by Pablo), one of Dr. Solis's PhD students who assisted with the creation of the geodatabase, in fall 2018.

results.title: Manitou Springs Skateboarding
results.description:
All the spots you need for a killer day skateboarding in beautiful Manitou Springs, Colorado! Like going fast? Got ya covered. Like big stairsets? Boom. Like some mellow transition? I got ya! Snap a deck on said big stariset? Theres a local skateshop right across the street. For the cheyahs!
(Don't forget to scroll a little west to find the skatepark and a few other spots!)
results.snippet: The skateshop, park, street spots, and hill bombs of Manitou Springs, Colorado.
results.licenseInfo: Watch out for cars and cops buddy!

results.name: CLP_abertsSquirrelRange08
results.title: CLP_abertsSquirrelRange2009
results.description: AbertsSquirrelOverallRange is an ESRI SDE Feature Class encompassing the observed range of a population of Aberts squirrel in Colorado. This information was derived from field personnel. A variety of data capture techniques were used including drawing on mylar overlays at 1:50,000 scale USGS county mapsheets and implementation of the SmartBoard Interactive Whiteboard using stand-up, real-time digitizing at various scales (Cowardin, M., M. Flenner. March 2003. Maximizing Mapping Resources. GeoWorld 16(3):32-35).</
results.snippet: This is part of the Natural Diversity Information Source, which provides information on wildlife distributions to public and private agencies and individuals,...
